docs.lead_paragraph: After compiling a database of customary rates for medical procedures, many insurance companies switched to a calculation based on Medicare rates, meaning higher costs for patients.

headline.seo: Health Insurers Switch Baseline for Out-of-Network Charges
headline.main: Insurers Alter Cost Formula, and Patients Pay More
headline.print_headline: Insurers Alter Cost Formula; Patients Pay

docs.abstract: Nation's largest health insurers have been switching to a new payment method that in most cases increases costs to the patient, despite landmark 2009 settlement with New York State that was expected to increase coverage for out-of-network care; though settlement required companies to underwrite a new database of customary doctors' fees with $95 million, it did not obligate them to use it; so companies nationwide rapidly shifted to another calculation method, based on Medicare rates, that usually reduces reimbursement substantially.
docs.snippet: After compiling a database of customary rates for medical procedures, many insurance companies switched to a calculation based on Medicare rates, meaning higher costs for patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a small group of researchers and their patients facing death, psychedelic drugs aren’t a hippie palliative. They’re a new way to approach the most dire time of life.

headline.main: How Psychedelic Drugs Can Help Patients Face Death
headline.print_headline: A Kaleidoscope at the End of the Tunnel

docs.abstract: Lauren Slater article on researchers across the country who are investigating the healing power of psychedelic drugs, like LSD and psilocybin, for fear and anxiety in terminal patients.
docs.snippet: For a small group of researchers and their patients facing death, psychedelic drugs aren’t a hippie palliative. They’re a new way to approach the most dire time of life.
